post.summary: Creates and starts a new OpenAPI scan.
post.description:
Creates a WebInspect settings file from a given REST API definition, then creates and starts a new scan with the same file. 

For advanced options, see the /scanner/wiswag (PUT/POST) and /scanner/scans (POST) endpoints.

###Examples###
~~~~
# Create and start a Swagger API scan
curl -X POST --header 'Content-type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "apiDefinitionUrl": "https://petstore.swagger.io/v2/swagger.json", "apiType": "swagger", "outputName": "PetStore" }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/APIScanner/OpenAPI/startAPIScan

# Create and start an OData API scan
curl -X POST --header 'Content-type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "apiDefinitionUrl": "https://services.odata.org/V4/TripPinServiceRW", "apiType": "odata", "outputName": "TripPin" }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/APIScanner/OpenAPI/startAPIScan
~~~~

parameters.name: startOpenAPIScanSettings
parameters.description: Options used to start an API scan.

post.description:
You can start a scan by uploading a Postman Collection file. WebInspect will audit any URLs in the collection.

Requires Newman command line tool (npm install -g newman). Add newman to System Path Environment variable.

`ScanName` - any alpha-numeric value, does not need to be unique.

`EnvironmentFile` - Postman file that contains a list of variables. need if collection can't be run without it

`Settings` - existing settings file used for scan. If not specified, Default settings are used. **Be sure to properly configure settings to access this site**

`AllowedHosts` - comma separated list of hosts to allow. If not specified, all hosts in the Postman Collection file are allowed.

`LoginMacro` - a webmacro file name. This file must exist in the WebInspect scan settings folder on the WebInspect machine.

`DisableAutoConfig` - this parameter instructs a Postman scan not to make any auto-configuration or analysis of the Postman collection before the scan. 

###Examples###
~~~~
Start a scan with default scan settings:
curl -v -F upload=@"C:\path\to\file\asdf.postman_collection.json" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/APIScanner/Postman/startPostmanScan

Start a scan with multiple postman collection files:
curl -v -F upload=@"C:\path\to\file\asdf.postman_collection.json" -F upload=@"C:\path\to\file\blah.postman_collection.json" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/APIScanner/Postman/startPostmanScan

Start a scan and give it a name:
curl -v -F upload=@"C:\path\to\file\blah.postman_collection.json" -F ScanName="postman_scan1" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/APIScanner/Postman/startPostmanScan

Start a scan with a specific scan settings file:
curl -v -F upload=@"C:\path\to\file\asdf.postman_collection.json" -F settings="postman_settings" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/APIScanner/Postman/startPostmanScan

Start a scan and override 'allowed hosts' (hosts separated by commas):
curl -v -F upload=@"C:\path\to\file\asdf.postman_collection.json" -F allowedHosts="http://myhost:80/,http://anotherhost:80" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/APIScanner/Postman/startPostmanScan

Start a scan with multiple postman collection files and non-default scan settings:
curl -v -F upload=@"C:\path\to\file\asdf.postman_collection.json" -F upload=@"C:\path\to\file\blah.postman_collection.json" -F settings="postman_settings" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/APIScanner/Postman/startPostmanScan

Start Postman scan with environment file 
curl -v -F upload=@"C:\path\to\file\asdf.postman_collection.json" -F environmentFile=@"C:\path\to\file\envfilename.json" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/APIScanner/Postman/startPostmanScan
~~~~

parameters.name: collectionFile
parameters.description: The Postman Collection file to upload.

parameters.name: environmentFile
parameters.description: The name of the environment file to use.

parameters.name: scanName
parameters.description: The name of the scan.

parameters.name: settings
parameters.description: The name of the scan settings file to use.

parameters.name: allowedHosts
parameters.description: Comma separated list of hosts to allow for the scan.

parameters.name: additionalPostmanFiles
parameters.description: Comma separated list of additional Postman Collection files to upload. (Specify full path)

parameters.name: loginMacro
parameters.description: A webmacro file name.

parameters.name: disableautoconfig
parameters.description: if true do not autoconfigure scan

post.description:
This endpoint will analyze data of postman collection/s and detect Authorization that using by collection and/or generate scan settings with Authorization  

You can create settings a scan by uploading a Postman Collection file. WebInspect will create audit only scan settings.

Requires Newman command line tool (npm install newman)

`ScanName` - any alpha-numeric value, does not need to be unique.

`EnvironmentFile` - Postman file that contains a list of variables. need if collection can't be run without it

`Settings` - existing settings file used for scan. If not specified, Default settings are used. **Be sure to properly configure settings to access this site**

`AllowedHosts` - comma separated list of hosts to allow. If not specified, all hosts in the Postman Collection file are allowed.

`SaveSettingsAs` - The name of the scan settings file to That will be saved as result of work. If this value is empty it will just show result of auto configure

###Examples###
~~~~
Start a scan with default scan settings:
curl -v -F upload=@"C:\path\to\file\asdf.postman_collection.json" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/APIScanner/Postman/configPostmanScan

Start a scan with a specific scan settings file:
curl -v -F upload=@"C:\path\to\file\asdf.postman_collection.json" -F settings="postman_settings" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/APIScanner/Postman/configPostmanScan

Start a scan and override 'allowed hosts' (hosts separated by commas):
curl -v -F upload=@"C:\path\to\file\asdf.postman_collection.json" -F allowedHosts="http://myhost:80/,http://anotherhost:80" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/APIScanner/Postman/configPostmanScan

~~~~

post.description:
The uploaded Postman collection file will be converted to a Macro file and stored in the WebInspect scan settings folder as defined by the WebInspect application setting. The default location is C:\ProgramData\HP\HP WebInspect\Settings.
The request must be formatted as `multipart/form-data`.
###Examples###
~~~~
#create macro file in the WebInspect scan settings folder
curl -X POST -F "file=@/local/path/Postman.json" -F logoutCondition="Access\sDenied"  http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/APIScanner/Postman/createPostmanMacro


#sample HTTP request
POST /webinspect/api/v1/APIScanner/Postman/createPostmanMacro HTTP/1.1
Host: myhost
Content-Length: xxx
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=----FormBoundaryd6c9T0mlmNbct6Uq

------FormBoundaryd6c9T0mlmNbct6Uq
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="macro"; filename="Postman.json"
Content-Type: application/json

{Postman collection file contents here}
------FormBoundaryd6c9T0mlmNbct6Uq
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="logoutCondition"

Access\sDenied
------FormBoundaryd6c9T0mlmNbct6Uq--

~~~~

parameters.name: collection
parameters.description: The Postman collection file to upload.

parameters.name: logoutCondition
parameters.description: Identifies the logout signature that indicates a logout state. This parameter accepts Regex Extensions.

parameters.name: environmentFile
parameters.description: The name of the environment file to use.

put.summary: Validate and fix an existing API Parser Config.
put.description:
`config` - An API parser config. * `proxy` - Access the API server using a proxy (optional).
◦ `host` - The hostname of the proxy server (required).
◦ `port` - The port number at which the proxy should be accessed (required).
◦ `username` - The username credential used to access the proxy server (optional).
◦ `password` - The password credential used to access the proxy server (optional).
* `authProviders` - Define authorization methods for the API server (optional).
◦ `usernameToken` - Options relating to Web Service Security UsernameTokens. (optional). Applicable only for SOAP scans.
· `type` - Describes the type of password being passed (required). Supported values: [`TEXT`, `HASH`]
· `timestamp` - Defines the type of timestamp to be appended (required).
Supported values include:
◘ `CREATED` - Include a timestamp with an indefinite lifespan.
◘ `FULL` - Include a timestamp with a fixed lifespan.
◘ `NONE` - Do not use a timestamp.
· `includeNonce` - Defines whether a nonce should be included (optional).
◦ `wsAddressing` - Options relating to Web Service Addressing. (optional). Applicable only for SOAP scans.
· `version` - Defines the XML namespace schema version (required).
Supported values include:
◘ `NONE` - Do not define a schema version.
◘ `WSA_0408` - Use the August 2004 schema.
◘ `WSA_0508` - Use the August 2005 schema.
· `to` - Overrides the endpoint to send responses to (optional).
◦ `clientCertificate` - Private certificate to validate the authenticity of the client (optional).
· `data` - The raw binary certificate, encoded as a Base64 string (required).
· `password` - The certificate's password (required).
◦ `serverCertificate` - Public certificate to validate the authenticity of the server (optional). Applicable only to SOAP scans.
· `data` - The raw binary certificate, encoded as a Base64 string (required).
· `password` - The certificate's password (optional).
◦ `fetch` - Use if the authorization token needs to be fetched after playing a login macro (optional).
· `macro` - The raw binary login macro to be played back, encoded as a Base64 string (required).
· `search` - The regex pattern by which to search the response body for the auth token (optional).
· `isolatedState` - Denotes whether each requestor thread should use a unique token (optional).
◦ `type` - Defines types of authentication to be used (required).
Supported categories and values include:
  Network Authentication: Select one as needed.
· `TRANSPORT_AUTHORIZATION` - Use a custom authentication scheme.
· `TRANSPORT_BEARER` - Use a pre-generated authentication token.
· `TRANSPORT_BASIC` - Use a Base64-encoded credential pair.
· `TRANSPORT_DIGEST` - Use a computed hash.
· `TRANSPORT_NTLM` - Use NT LAN Manager authentication.
  Custom Request Header: Add multiple as needed.
· `TRANSPORT_CUSTOM_HEADER` - Use a customized header.
  Client Certificate: Add one as needed.
· `TRANSPORT_CERTIFICATE` - Use a client certificate.
  Message Based: Applicable only for SOAP scans. Select one as needed.
· `MESSAGE_USERNAMETOKEN` - Use an encrypted username token.
· `MESSAGE_CERTIFICATE` - Use a pair of client/server certificates.
◦ `header` - Defines the name of the HTTP header sent
Applicable when `type` is `TRANSPORT_CUSTOM_HEADER`.
◦ `name` - Defines the type of authorization token being passed (optional).
Applicable only when `type` is `TRANSPORT_AUTHORIZATION`.
◦ `value` - Defines the value of the authorization token (optional).
◦ `username` - The username credential used to access the API server (optional).
Applicable when `type` is `TRANSPORT_BASIC`, `TRANSPORT_DIGEST`, `TRANSPORT_NTLM`, or `MESSAGE_USERNAMETOKEN`.
◦ `password` - The password credential used to access the API server (optional).
Applicable when `type` is `TRANSPORT_BASIC`, `TRANSPORT_DIGEST`, `TRANSPORT_NTLM`, or `MESSAGE_USERNAMETOKEN`.
* `apiDefinition` - The URL, file location, or plaintext representation of a supported API definition (required). * `excludeOperations` - A list of operation IDs that should be excluded from the output (optional). * `includeOperations` - A list of operation IDs that should be included from the output (optional). * `excludeHTTPMethods` - A list of HTTP methods to be excluded from the output (optional; example: ["GET", "PUT"]). * `preferredContentType` - Sets a preferred `Content-Type` value for the request payload (optional; example: `application/json`). * `schemes` - A list of URI schemes for which output should be produced (e.g. `http`, `https`) (optional). * `host` - Overrides the host in the API definition (optional). * `servicePath` - The base path of the API (optional). * `parameterRules` - A list of parameter-specific rules to exclude, replace, or inject parameters into the output (optional).
◦ `name` - The parameter name to match (required).
◦ `value` - The parameter value to substitute or inject (required).
◦ `fileName` - Replaces the filename attribute of a given `multipart/form file` entry (optional). Applicable only if `type` is `file`.
◦ `location` - The location of the parameter to be matched (optional).
Supported values include:
· `any` - Match any valid location.
· `body` - Must be in the request body.
· `header` - Must be in a request header.
· `path` - Must be in the URL segment.
· `query` - Must be in the query string.
◦ `type` - The underlying type of the parameter to be matched (optional).
Supported values include:
· `any` - Match any type.
· `number` - Must be numeric.
· `boolean` - Must be a truth value (i.e. `true` or `false`).
· `string` - Must be an alphanumeric value.
· `file` - Must be a file.
· `date` - Must be a date or time value.
· `guid` - Must be a globally unique identifier (GUID).
◦ `includeOperations` - An array of operation IDs to be included (optional).
◦ `excludeOperations` - An array of operation IDs to be excluded (optional).
◦ `inject` - Defines whether the parameter should always be injected in `location`, regardless of if a matching name/type is found (optional).
◦ `base64Decode` - Denotes whether `value` is a Base64 string and requires decoding (optional).
* `type` - The type of API being parsed (required). Supported values: [`Swagger`, `OData`, `GraphQL`, `gRPC`, `SOAP`] * `apiVersion` - Sets the preferred API operation protocol version (optional). Applicable only if `type` is `SOAP`.
Supported values include:
◦ `legacy` - Force use of the lowest supported protocol version.
◦ `mixed` - Use the newest available supported protocol version.
◦ `newest` - Force use of the newest supported protocol version.
`encodeResult` - Controls the formatting of the returned `APIParserConfig`. `true`: Return an encoded Base64 string. This can be used as-is when creating a new scan settings file or overriding an existing scan configuration. `false`: Return a JSON string. This can be useful for debugging. `authCredentials` - HTTP Authorization credentials to be used for accessing the API. (optional) Example: `Basic YWxhZGRpbjpvcGVuc2VzYW1l`

post.description:
This endpoint will allow to verify connectivity to your application using start scan URL.

`startURL` - a valid fully qualified url, including scheme, host and port. (Required)
`("startURL":"http://myhost:80/some/path/login.php")`

`userAgent` - allows to configure predefined user agent or use custom user agent string (Optional).
* `standard`    - options are: `firefox`, `internetexplorer`, `chrome`, `iphone`, `ipad`, `android`, `windowsphone`, `windowsrt`, `none`. (Optional).
* `custom`      - custom user agent string. (Optional).
If you would like to use `custom` user agent string then `standard` should be set to `none`
`("userAgent":{"standard":"firefox"})`
`("userAgent":{"standard":"none","custom":"my custom user agent string"})`

`proxy` - allows to verify connectivity through configured proxy server (Optional).
* `proxyMode`           -  options are: `none`, `standard`, `socks4`, `socks5`, `pacUrl`. (Required).
* `proxyServer`         - proxy server hostname or IP address. (Required).
* `proxyPort`           - proxy server port number. (Required)
* `proxyPacUrl`         - proxy server autoconfiguration PAC file URL. (Optional).
* `proxyAuthType`       - options are `none`, `basic`, `ntlm`, `kerberos`, `digest`, `automatic`, `negotiate`.    (Optional).
* `proxyAuthUsername`   - proxy authentication username. (Optional).
* `proxyAuthPassword`   - proxy authentication password. (Optional).
* `proxyBypass`         - bypass proxy semicolon separated list (Optional).
`("proxy": {"proxyMode":"standard","proxyServer":"myProxyHostOrIP","proxyPort":"8080"})`
if you would like to use `proxyPacUrl` then `proxyMode` should be set to `pacUrl`


`networkAuthentication` - allows to verify connectivity when your application requires network authentication.  (Optional).
* `authType`        - options are:  `none`, `basic`, `ntlm`, `adfs_cbt`, `kerberos`, `digest`, `automatic`, `negotiate`. (Required).
* `authUsername`    - authentication username
* `authPassword`    - authentication password
`("networkAuthentication":{"authType":"digest","authUsername":"foo","authPassword":"bar"})`


`clientCertificate` - either the location of the client certificate in the Windows certificate store OR the raw client certificate. (Optional).
If you would like to reference a client certificate in the Windows certificate store, use these fields:
* `isGlobal`    - if true, look for `StoreName` in the Local Machine machine hive. Otherwise look for `StoreName` in the Current User hive.
* `storeName`   - the system store name where the certificate is located. The predefined systems stores are: MY, Root, Trust, CA.
* `thumbprint`  - the certificate hash that uniquely identifies the client certificate.
If you would like to embed the client certificate, use this field:
* `bytes`       - the raw client certificate bytes in base64 encoded format. If this field is set then the values of `isGlobal`, `storeName` and `thumbprint` are ignored.
* `password`    - client pfx certificate password. (Optional).

`httpHeaders` - list of additional HTTP request headers which will be used during connectivity verification. (Optional).
`("httpHeaders":[{"name":"MyHeaderName","value":"MyHeaderValue"}])`

`settingsName` - allows to verify connectivity using network or proxy authentication username and password from scan settings file. (Optional).

###Examples###
~~~~
#verify connectivity to your application using start scan URL only
curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "startURL": "http://myhost:80/some/path/login.php" }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/configuration/verifysite

#verify connectivity to your application using start scan URL and proxy server
curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "startURL": "http://myhost:80/some/path/login.php", "proxy": {"proxyMode":"standard","proxyServer":"myProxyHostOrIP","proxyPort":"8080"} }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/configuration/verifysite

#verify connectivity to your application using start scan URL and network authentication
curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "startURL": "http://myhost:80/some/path/login.php", "networkAuthentication":{"authType":"digest","authUsername":"foo","authPassword":"bar"} }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/configuration/verifysite
~~~~

parameters.name: verifySite
parameters.description: Start Scan URL configuration

post.description:
Create a Selenium WebDriver macro. The file will be placed in the WebInspect scan settings folder as defined by the WebInspect application setting (the default location is C:\ProgramData\HP\HP WebInspect\Settings).

**Security Impact: This feature adds the ability to execute command remotely to we strongly recommend to use API authentication.**

The selenium properties are defined as follows:

`VerifyMacro` - true or false value. Default value: true. if it set to true API performs verification of Selenium macro before it saves.
`("VerifyMacro":true)`

`SettingsName` - any alpha-numeric value. Default value: `Default`. Uses if Selenium macro performs verification (gets proxy, certificate, etc from settings)
`("SettingsName":"ScanSettingsName")`

`Name` - any alpha-numeric value. Required value. Macro will be saved by this name.
`("Name":"Macro1")`

`Command` - any value. Required value. This is Command that will be executed to run Selenium script
`("Command":"C:\\nunit3-console.exe \"D:\\Unit Tests\\UnitTest.dll\" ")`
Note: all double quotes inside 'command' parameter should be escaped with the \\" and splash (\\) should be escaped with the \\\\

`AllowedHosts` - an array of Allowed Hosts. If this value is not set that we will try to find it during the verification phase (VerifyMacro will be set to true). This value needs to marks hosts that can be added to scan and audited.
`("AllowedHosts":["http://hostname","https://hostname"])`

`LogoutCondition` -  Identifies the logout signature that indicates a logout state. This parameter accepts Regex Extensions.

`WorkingDirectory` - Path to Working directory. Optional value. Some Selenium WebDriver Scripts need to specify the working directory for functioning
`("WorkingDirectory":"C:\\selenium\\project1\\")`

###Examples###
~~~~
# Create Selenium macro in Windows Command line
curl -X POST --header "Content-Type: application/json" -d "{\"VerifyMacro\":true,\"name\": \"test\",\"command\": \"D:\\tmp\\selenium_wd\\bin\\net35\\nunit3-console.exe \\\"D:\\tmp\\selenium_wd\\selenium_c_sharp-master\\Selenium\\bin\\Debug\\Selenium.dll\\\"\",\"allowedHosts\": [\"http://scanme2\"]}" "http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/configuration/selenium/macro"
~~~~

parameters.name: selenium
parameters.description: Selenium

post.description:
You can create a new scan settings by specifying a `baseSettingsName` settings file that exists in the WebInspect scan settings folder. Optional overrides provide a way to make changes to certain fields in the referenced `baseSettingsName` scan settings file. Macros referenced in the overrides field must be located in the WebInspect scan settings folder for the API server to find them. The default location for scan settings is C:\ProgramData\HP\HP WebInspect\Settings. The override properties are defined as follows: `scanName` - any alpha-numeric value, does not need to be unique. `("scanName":"My Scan Name 123")` `startUrls` - a list of valid, fully qualified urls, including scheme, host and port. This field is only used if `StartOption` is `Url`. `("startUrls":["http://myhost:80/some/path/login.php", "http://anotherhost:80/index.html"])` `startOption` - options are: `Url`, `Macro`, `File`, `Api` `("startOption":"Url")` `crawlAuditMode` - modes are: `CrawlOnly`, `AuditOnly`, `CrawlAndAudit` `("crawlAuditMode":"CrawlAndAudit")` `scanStrategy` - When to perform the site Audit relative to a Crawl. Applicable only when `crawlAuditMode` is `CrawlAndAudit`. * `Simultaneously` - Crawl and audit at the same time to maximize scan speed (default). * `Sequentially` - Crawl the entire site before auditing. `webServiceScan` - allows to configure SOAP Web Service Scan: * `wsdName` - Webservice Test Design File name * `inheritWsdProxy` - use Webservice Test Design File proxy settings * `inheritWsdAuth` - use Webservice Test Design File network authentication settings `apiScan` - Configuration options for API scans: * `parserConfig` - A Base64 encoded string of an API Parser Config. To generate one, use the `configuration/apiParserConfig` family of endpoints. * `definitionUrl` - URL of the API definition. * `type` - The type of API to be parsed (`Swagger`, `OData`, `Postman`, `GraphQL`, `gRPC`, `SOAP`) * `definitionAuth` - A string value designating the bearer token required to authenticate in order to retrieve the API Definition when using WISwag, if necessary(only available for ODATA and Swagger) `sharedThreads` - a number between 1 and 75 indicating the number of shared threads that the crawler and auditor should use (default is 1, meaning a single threaded scan). **`SharedThreads` is not compatible with `CrawlThreads` and `AuditThreads`. If `SharedThreads` is set, `CrawlThreads` and `AuditThreads` will be ignored.** `("sharedThreads":"1")` `crawlThreads` - a number between 1 and 25 indicating the number of threads that the crawler should use (default is 1). **`SharedThreads` is not compatible with `CrawlThreads` and `AuditThreads`. If `SharedThreads` is set, `CrawlThreads` and `AuditThreads` will be ignored.** `("crawlThreads":"1")` `auditThreads` - a number between 1 and 50 indicating the number of threads that the auditor should use (default is 10). **`SharedThreads` is not compatible with `CrawlThreads` and `AuditThreads`. If `SharedThreads` is set, `CrawlThreads` and `AuditThreads` will be ignored.** `("auditThreads":"10")` `LoginMacroAutoGen` - allows to configure automatic login macro generation (Optional): * `username` - login webform username * `password` - login webform password * `startUrl` - start scan URL or login webform URL (Optional) `loginMacro` - a webmacro file name. This file must exist in the WebInspect scan settings folder on the WebInspect machine. `("loginMacro":"mylogin")` `workflowMacros` - an array of webmacro file names to be used as workflow macros. These files must exist in the WebInspect scan settings folder on the WebInspect machine. `("workflowMacros":["workflow1","workflow2"])` `allowedHosts` - an array of allowed host:port entries. Hosts found in `StartUrls` are automatically added to the allowed hosts list. Use the special value "\*" to add all hosts found in workflow macros, login macros and start urls to allowed hosts. **Caution! This is a convenience feature, and it can cause the scanner to go out of scope.** `("allowedHosts":["zero.webappsecurity.com:80", "zero.webappsecurity.com:443", "myhost:8888"])` `("allowedHosts":["\*"])` `policyId` - an integer representing the policy id OR the GUID representing the policy unique id. See /securebase/policy for a list of available policies. `("policyId":1)` `("policyId":"cb72a7c2-9207-4ee7-94d0-edd14a47c15c")` `PolicyPath` - the full path to the custom policy file. `("PolicyPath":"C:\ProgramData\HP\HP WebInspect\Policies\MyCustomPolicy.policy")` `checkIDs` - an array of check IDs. A custom audit policy will be created from this list and used for the scan. `("checkIDs":[100,200,300])` `tcMacroParameters` - override parameters defined in TruClient macros. The macros must exist in the scan settings and the parameters must exist in the macro. `("tcMacroParameters":{"mylogin":{"param1":"value1","param2":"value2"}})` `smartCredentials` - override the smart credentials defined in a session-based macro. The macro must exist in the scan settings and smart credentials must be enabled in the macro. `("smartCredentials":["myusername","mypassword"])` `userAgent` - allows to configure predefined user agent or use custom user agent string: * `standard` - options are: `firefox`, `internetexplorer`, `chrome`, `iphone`, `ipad`, `android`, `windowsphone`, `windowsrt`, `none`. (Optional). * `custom` - custom user agent string. (Optional). If you would like to use `custom` user agent string then `standard` should be set to `none` `("userAgent":{"standard":"firefox"})` `("userAgent":{"standard":"none","custom":"my custom user agent string"})` `proxy` - allows to configure proxy server: * `proxyMode` - options are: `none`, `standard`, `socks4`, `socks5`, `pacUrl`. (Required). * `proxyServer` - proxy server hostname or IP address. (Required). * `proxyPort` - proxy server port number. (Required) * `proxyPacUrl` - proxy server autoconfiguration PAC file URL. (Optional). * `proxyAuthType` - options are `none`, `basic`, `ntlm`, `kerberos`, `digest`, `automatic`, `negotiate`. (Optional). * `proxyAuthUsername` - proxy authentication username. (Optional). * `proxyAuthPassword` - proxy authentication password. (Optional). * `proxyBypass` - bypass proxy semicolon separated list (Optional). `("proxy": {"proxyMode":"standard","proxyServer":"myProxyHostOrIP","proxyPort":"8080"})` if you would like to use `proxyPacUrl` then `proxyMode` should be set to `pacUrl` `networkCredentials` - network authentication username and password. Use the `NetworkAuthenticationMode` setting to specify the authentication mode. `("networkCredentials":["myusername","mypassword"])` `NetworkAuthenticationMode` - modes are: `None`, `Basic`, `Digest`, `Kerberos`, `Negotiate`, `NTLM`, `ADFS_CBT`, `Automatic`. Specifies the network authentication mode when using `NetworkCredentials`. `("networkAuthenticationMode":"Basic")` `ScopedPaths` - list of folder restrictions. Paths found in `StartUrls` are automatically added to the `ScopedPaths` list. This setting interacts with `ScanScope` to determine which paths will be crawled during a scan. If `ScopedPaths` is specified, `ScanScope` must also be specified. `("scopedPaths":["/ancestor/path1/","/ancestor/path2/"])` `ScanScope` - options are: `Unrestricted`, `Self`, `Children`, `Ancestors`. If `ScopedPaths` is specified, `ScanScope` must also be specified. `("scanScope":"Unrestricted")` This setting interacts with `ScopedPaths` to restrict the crawler to specific paths within a web site: * `Unrestricted` - `ScopedPaths` is ignored. Crawl all discovered paths, but respect allowed host rules. * `Self` - limit crawl strictly to paths listed in `ScopedPaths`. Referring to the example in `ScopedPaths`, /ancestor/path1/ would be allowed but /ancestor/ and /ancestor/path1/child/ would be excluded from crawl. * `Children` - limit crawl to paths listed in `ScopedPaths` and their children. Referring to the example in `ScopedPaths`, /ancestor/path1/ and /ancestor/path1/child/ would be allowed but /ancestor/ would be excluded from crawl. * `Ancestors` - limit crawl to paths listed in `ScopedPaths` and their parents. Referring to the example in `ScopedPaths`, /ancestor/path1/ and /ancestor/ would be allowed but /ancestor/path1/child/ would be excluded from crawl. `ClientCertificate` - either the location of the client certificate in the Windows certificate store OR the raw client certificate. * `Enabled` - User can manually disable(false) or enable(true) it. Default it will be true if `StoreName` and `SerialNumber` or `Bytes` provided in other cases false. If you want to reference a client certificate in the Windows certificate store, use these fields: * `IsGlobal` - if true, look for `StoreName` in the Local Machine machine hive. Otherwise look for `StoreName` in the Current User hive. * `StoreName` - the system store name where the certificate is located. The predefined systems stores are: MY, Root, Trust, CA. * `SerialNumber` - the serial number that uniquely identifies the client certificate. If you want to embed the client certificate, use this field: * `Bytes` - the raw client certificate bytes in base64 encoded format. If this field is set then the values of `IsGlobal`, `StoreName` and `SerialNumber` are ignored. **Caution! When using the `Bytes` option, the client certificate is embedded in the scan settings and may be visible to other users.** * `Password` - client pfx certificate password. (Optional). `redundantPageDetection` - Compares the page structure of each crawled page to identify and exclude processing of redundant resources. * `enabled` - `true` to enable the Redundant Page Detection feature, or `false` to disable it. If undefined in both base settings and request, defaults to `false`. * `pageSimilarityThresholdPercentage` - How similar a page must be to another to be considered redundant, in terms of a percentage.
This value **must** be an integer within [1, 100]. If undefined in both base settings and request, defaults to 95. * `includedTagAttributes` - A comma-separated list of tag attributes to be included in the page structure comparison. If undefined or empty in both base settings and request, defaults to `"id,class"`. `ProxySettingsType` - indicates the Proxy Settings type. This value is ignored if `proxy` is specified. `("ProxySettingsType":"AutoDetect")` `SPAEnabledOption` - Indicates the Single-Page Applications enabled option. `("SPAEnabledOption":"Auto")` `SessionExclusions` - list of Other Exlusion/Rejection Criteria. `("SessionExclusions": [{"name": "exclusionName", "reject": true, "exclude": true, "targets": [{ "targetType": "QueryParameter", "targetName": "targetNameValue", "matchType": "Matches", "matchString": "matchStringValue" }] }])` ###Examples### ~~~~ #create new scan settings based on Default scan settings, set the scan name to "My Scan Name", use a login macro named tclogin, and use the "Criticals and Highs" policy curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "baseSettingsName": "Default", "overrides": { "scanName": "My Scan Name", "loginMacro": "tclogin", "policyId":1008 } }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/configuration/scansettings/create #create new scan settings based on scan settings file named MySettings.xml, use Basic network authentication and set the username to "myusername" and the password to "mypassword" curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "baseSettingsName": "MySettings", "overrides": { "networkAuthenticationMode": "basic", "networkCredentials": ["myusername","mypassword"] } }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/configuration/scansettings/create #create new scan settings based on Default scan settings, use a TruClient based login macro named tclogin.webmacro, set the macro parameter named "username" to "myusername" and the parameter named "password" to "mypassword" (these parameters must exist in the macro) curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "baseSettingsName": "Default", "overrides": { "loginMacro": "tclogin", "tcMacroParameters": { "tclogin": { "username":"myusername", "password":"mypassword" } } } }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/configuration/scansettings/create #create new scan settings based on Default scan settings, change the scan type to a workflow macro scan, use the workflow macro named MyWorkflow, and set the scan mode to audit only curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "baseSettingsName": "Default", "overrides": { "startOption": "macro", "workflowMacros": ["MyWorkflow"], "crawlAuditMode": "auditOnly"} }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/configuration/scansettings/create #create new scan settings based on Default scan settings, set the start url to http://myhost/appPath/, restrict the scan to only crawl within /appPath/ and any sub-folders under /appPath/ curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "baseSettingsName": "Default", "overrides": { "startUrls": ["http://myhost/appPath/"], "scanScope": "children"} }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/configuration/scansettings/create #create new scan settings based on Default scan settings, set the start url to http://myhost/appPath/, restrict the scan to only crawl within /appPath/ and /appPath/level1/ curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "baseSettingsName": "Default", "overrides": { "startUrls": ["http://myhost/appPath/"], "scanScope": "self", "scopedPaths": ["/appPath/","/appPath/level1/"] } }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/configuration/scansettings/create ~~~~

parameters.name: scansettings
parameters.description: Options used to start a scan. `settingsName` is required. `overrides` and `reuseScan` are optional. When `reuseScan` parameters are specified, `settingsName` should still be sent, but it is ignored and should be an empty value. In the scan reuse case the settings from the reused scan will be used. Overrides can be applied to reuse scan settings.

delete.description:
Delete Selenium support folder
###Examples###
~~~~
#Delete Selenium support folder
curl -X DELETE http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/configuration/selenium/folder/{foldername}
~~~~

get.summary: Get a list of all running proxy instances.
get.description:
Get a list of all running proxy instances.
###Examples###
~~~~
#get all running proxy instances
curl http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/proxy
~~~~

post.description:
You can specify a value for the proxy identifier, network interface address and port (or omit any or all of these values).

The instance ID can be any alpha-numeric value.

Sending an empty POST body creates a new proxy with a random instance ID on the first available port on the default network interface address (127.0.0.1).

Any proxies created through the REST API are destroyed when the API server stops.
###Examples###
~~~~
#create a new proxy with a specific instance ID on a specific port on a specific network interface. 
curl -d "instanceId=123abc&address=192.168.1.20&port=8123" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/proxy

#create a new proxy with a random instance ID on any available port on the default network interface. 
curl -d "" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/proxy
~~~~

get.summary: Get the WebInspect root certificate.
get.description:
When connecting to a site through a WebInspect proxy over HTTPS, the WebInspect root certificate must be installed on the client machine to avoid triggering invalid certificate alerts.
###Examples###
~~~~
#Get the WebInspect root certificate. You must install this certificate on the client machine if you are connecting to a remote proxy and accessing a site using HTTPS.
curl -o wirootcert.crt http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/proxy/rootcert
~~~~

get.summary: Get a list of all network interface addresses.
get.description:
Get a list of all network interface addresses.
###Examples###
~~~~
#get all network interface addresses
curl http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/proxy/interfaces
~~~~

get.summary: Get information about a specific proxy instance.
get.description:
Get information about a specific proxy instance.
###Examples###
~~~~
#get information about a specific proxy instance
curl http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/proxy/{instanceId}
~~~~

parameters.name: instanceId
parameters.description: The proxy instance ID.

put.summary: Clear the traffic for a specific proxy instance.
put.description:
All captured traffic is removed from the proxy instance. The proxy instance is not deleted.
###Examples###
~~~~
#Clear out the existing traffic for the specified proxy.
curl -X PUT -d "" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/proxy/{instanceId}?action=reset
~~~~

parameters.name: instanceId
parameters.description: The proxy instance ID.

parameters.name: action
parameters.description: The value for `action` must be `reset`.

delete.description:
The proxy shutdowns and stops collecting traffic. The instance no longer responds to commands. Any unsaved traffic is lost.
###Examples###
~~~~
#delete proxy with specific ID
curl -X DELETE http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/proxy/{instanceId}
~~~~

parameters.name: instanceId
parameters.description: The proxy instance ID.

get.summary: Export the proxy traffic and download the results.
get.description:
Export the proxy traffic and download the results.
###Examples###
~~~~
#download proxy traffic as native WebInspect format
curl -o ./mycapture.tsf http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/proxy/{instanceId}.tsf

#download proxy traffic as a workflow macro
curl -o ./mymacro.webmacro http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/proxy/{instanceId}.webmacro

#download proxy capture as scan settings (scan setting is configured as an audit only workflow scan using the proxy traffic as the workflow macro).
curl -o ./myworkflow.xml http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/proxy/{instanceId}.xml
~~~~

parameters.name: instanceId
parameters.description: The proxy instance ID.

parameters.name: extension
parameters.description:
Valid `extensions` are:
* `tsf` - Export proxy traffic to native WebInspect proxy format
* `webmacro` - Export proxy traffic to a workflow macro
* `xml` - Export proxy traffic to a workflow macro and then embed that macro into a scan settings file

put.summary: Export the proxy traffic and save the results to the server.
put.description:
Instead of downloading the proxy traffic, it can be useful to store the results directly on the WebInspect machine.
###Examples###
~~~~
#Save the proxy as a settings file named "{instanceId}.xml" to the WebInspect machine without needing to download it locally. An existing file is NOT replaced.
curl -X PUT -d http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/proxy/{instanceId}.xml?action=save

#Save the proxy as a web macro file named "{instanceId}.webmacro" to the WebInspect machine without needing to download it locally. An existing file is replaced.
curl -X PUT -d "" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/proxy/{instanceId}.webmacro?action=overwrite

# Find a settings file on the WI machine matching the name "{instanceId}.xml" and delete it if it exists.
curl -X PUT -d "" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/proxy/{instanceId}.xml?action=delete
~~~~

parameters.name: instanceId
parameters.description: The proxy instance ID.

parameters.name: extension
parameters.description:
Valid `extensions` are:
* `tsf` - Export proxy traffic to native WebInspect proxy format
* `webmacro` - Export proxy traffic to a workflow macro
* `xml` - Export proxy traffic to a workflow macro and then embed that macro into a scan settings file

parameters.name: action
parameters.description:
Valid `actions` are:
* `save` - Save the proxy traffic, do not overwrite an existing file
* `overwrite` - Save the proxy traffic, overwrite an existing file
* `delete` - Delete an existing file, if it exists

get.summary: Get a list of all available scan files.
get.description:
Get a list of available scan files.
###Examples###
~~~~
#get a list of available scan files
curl http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scan
~~~~

post.description:
The uploaded scan file will be placed in the WebInspect scan settings folder as defined by the WebInspect application setting (the default location is C:\ProgramData\HP\HP WebInspect\Settings).
The request must be formatted as `multipart/form-data`.
###Examples###
~~~~
#upload a scan file to the WebInspect scan settings folder
curl -F "file=@/local/path/myScan.scan" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scan


#sample HTTP request
POST /webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scan HTTP/1.1
Host: myhost
Content-Length: xxx
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=----FormBoundaryd6c9T0mlmNbct6Uq

------FormBoundaryd6c9T0mlmNbct6Uq
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="ScanFile"; filename="ScanFile.scan"
Content-Type: application/zip

{scan file contents here}
------FormBoundaryd6c9T0mlmNbct6Uq--

~~~~

parameters.name: scan
parameters.description: The scan file to upload.

get.summary: Get a list of available saved macro files.
get.description:

#get a list of available macros

post.description:

The request must be formatted as `multipart/form-data`.
###Examples###
~~~~
#upload a macro file to the WebInspect scan settings folder
curl -X POST -F "file=@/local/path/myMacro.webmacro" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/macro


#sample HTTP request
POST /webinspect/api/v1/scanner/macro HTTP/1.1
Host: myhost
Content-Length: xxx
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=----FormBoundaryd6c9T0mlmNbct6Uq

------FormBoundaryd6c9T0mlmNbct6Uq
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="macro"; filename="myMacro.webmacro"
Content-Type: text/xml

{macro file contents here}
------FormBoundaryd6c9T0mlmNbct6Uq--

~~~~

parameters.name: macro
parameters.description: The macro file to upload.

delete.description:
This will remove a specific settings file.
###Examples###

get.summary: Get the status of a specific scan.
get.description:
This will return the current status of the scan. This can also be used to wait for the status to change. The scan status can be one of the following values:
* `Running` - the scan is currently running.
* `NotRunning` - the scan has been created, but is not running. This could be either a new scan that is still initializing or a paused scan.
* `Complete` - the scan has finished normally.
* `Interrupted` - the scan has stopped running due to an error condition.

###Examples###
~~~~
#get the current status of a scan
curl http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans/{scanId}?action=GetCurrentStatus

#wait until the scan status changes to a non-running state (Complete or Interrupted).
curl http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans/{scanId}?action=WaitForStatusChange
~~~~

parameters.name: scanId
parameters.description: The scan GUID.

parameters.name: action
parameters.description:
An optional value to control when the status is returned. Options are:
* `GetCurrentStatus` - return the scan status immediately. This is the default behavior if no `action` parameter is provided.
* `WaitForStatusChange` - if the scan status is Running, wait for the scan status to change and then return the new value.

If the scan status is not `Running`, the scan status is returned immediately. Otherwise, the response may take some time and the connection could timeout depending on the way your client is configured. If a timeout occurs, increase the timeout setting of your client.

put.summary: Add sessions to an existing scan.
put.description:
This endpoint provides a way to add crawl sessions and vulnerabilities that were discovered outside of WebInspect to an existing scan.
The `issues` object contains the following fields which require additional explanation:
* `type` - numeric ID that is specific to the external application adding the issue
* `probability` - a number representing the confidence value for this issue. The range is from 0 to 4, where 0 = no confidence, 4 = certainty.
* `severity` - a number representing the severity of the issue. The range is from 0 to 4, where 0 = no severity/informational, 1 = low, 2 = medium, 3 = high, 4 = critical.

###Examples###
~~~~
#add a session with no vulnerabilities to a scan
curl -X PUT -d "[{\"port\":80,\"protocol\":\"http\",\"host\":\"zero.webappsecurity.com\",\"requestBase64\":\"base64 encoded request\",\"responseBase64\":\"base64 encoded response\", \"issues\":null}]" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans/{scanId}

#add a session with a single vulnerability to a scan
curl -X PUT -d "[{\"port\":80,\"protocol\":\"http\",\"host\":\"zero.webappsecurity.com\",\"requestBase64\":\"base64 encoded request\",\"responseBase64\":\"base64 encoded response\", \"issues\":[{\"name\":\"My Issue Name (XSS, SQLi, etc)\",\"type\":12345,\"probability\":4,\"severity\":4,\"summary\":\"Issue summary text here.\",\"execution\":\"Description of how to execute this issue.\",\"fix\":\"How to remediate this issue.\",\"referenceInfo\":\"Additional information about this issue (external links, etc)\"}]}]" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans/{scanId}
~~~~

parameters.name: scanId
parameters.description: The scan GUID.

parameters.name: externalSessions
parameters.description:
A list of sessions to add to the scan. To add a session with no vulnerabilities, leave the "issues" field null.

Note that this parameter is an array of session objects.

get.summary: Export scan data to one of several formats.
get.description:
The scan is exported to the specified format and downloaded to your client. If `extension` is `xml`, an optional `detailType` may be specified. This will export the scan data to an XML format and is the equivalent of using File>Export>Scan Details in the WebInspect UI.
###Examples###
~~~~
#get the scan results in the native WebInspect format
curl http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans/{scanId}.scan

#get the scan results in simplified XML format
curl http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans/{scanId}.xml?detailType=Comments

#get the scan results in fpr format
curl http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans/{scanId}.fpr
~~~~

parameters.name: scanId
parameters.description: The scan GUID.

parameters.name: extension
parameters.description:
The `extension` value specifies the export type. It must be one of:
* `scan` - Export scan in native WebInspect scan format.
* `xml` - Export scan in XML format, see the `detailType` parameter for more informations.
* `settings` - Export scan settings.
* `fpr` - Export scan in fpr format.
* `crawl` - Export crawl sessions.
* `issue` - Export vulnerable sessions.
* `all` - Export crawl and vulnerable sessions.

parameters.name: detailType
parameters.description:
The `detailType` value should only be set if `extension` is `xml`. The default value is `Full`. The value of `detailType` must be one of:
* `Full`
* `Comments`
* `HiddenFields`
* `Script`
* `SetCookies`
* `WebForms`
* `Urls`
* `Requests`
* `Sessions`
* `Emails`
* `Parameters`
* `OffsiteLinks`
* `Vulnerabilities`

#get scans that are "Complete"
curl http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans?Status=Complete

#get scans that are "Complete" that started after January 14, 2015 at 3pm
curl http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans?Status=Complete&StartsAfter=2015-01-14T15:00:00
~~~~

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Filter scans by scan name. This value is treated as a regular expression.

parameters.name: status
parameters.description: Filter scans by status.

parameters.name: startsAfter
parameters.description: Filter scans by start date/time. The expected format is YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS

put.summary: Import a scan from a scan file.
put.description:
This will import a scan from a previously uploaded scan file. Scan files should first be uploaded via POST /scanner/scan `scanFileName` - The name of the scan file to be imported, with or without the .scan file extension (required). `keepAfterImport` - `true` if the scan file should be kept after the import process completes, or `false` if it should be deleted (required).
If the import process fails, this parameter will be ignored, and the scan file will always be kept.
If needed, the scan file can be deleted later with DELETE /scanner/scan/{scanName}. `newScanId` - The scan ID to be assigned to the scan upon importation (optional). The following options are supported: * `null` - The imported scan will use a new randomly generated GUID. * An empty GUID (`{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}`) - The imported scan will inherit the same ID it had as originally exported.
If this scan was previously imported, the import operation may fail when using this option. * A user-defined case-insensitive GUID, curly braces (`{}`) are optional. When using, please validate the following: * The GUID should be well-formed. If the GUID is malformed, the behavior for a `null` GUID will apply and therefore return an unexpected value. * The GUID should not conflict with an existing scan ID (GET /scanner/scans/{scanId}). The import operation may fail if there is an ID collision. ###Examples### ~~~~ #Import myScan.scan using a generated ID, delete after importing curl -X PUT --header 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{ "scanFileName" : "myScan.scan", "keepAfterImport": false }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans #Import myScan using an inherited ID, keep after importing curl -X PUT --header 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{ "scanFileName" : "myScan", "keepAfterImport": true, "newScanId": "{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}" }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans #Import myScan using a custom ID, delete after importing curl -X PUT --header 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{ "scanFileName" : "myScan", "keepAfterImport": false, "newScanId": "b08a1a75-efe6-4286-ba56-6a1144657f7c" }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans ~~~~

parameters.name: importScanOptions
parameters.description: Options used for importing a scan.

400.description: The import operation failed. Refer to the response body for details.

404.description: The requested scan file was not found.

post.description:
You can create a new scan by specifying a settings file that exists in the WebInspect scan settings folder. Optional overrides provide a way to make changes to certain fields in the referenced scan settings file. Macros referenced in the overrides field must be located in the WebInspect scan settings folder for the API server to find them. The default location for scan settings is C:\ProgramData\HP\HP WebInspect\Settings. The override properties are defined as follows: `ScanName` - any alpha-numeric value, does not need to be unique. `("ScanName":"My Scan Name 123")` `StartUrls` - a list of valid, fully qualified urls, including scheme, host and port. This field is only used if `StartOption` is `Url`. `("StartUrls":["http://myhost:80/some/path/login.php", "http://anotherhost:80/index.html"])` `StartOption` - options are: `Url`, `Macro`, `File`, `Api` `("StartOption":"Url")` `CrawlAuditMode` - modes are: `CrawlOnly`, `AuditOnly`, `CrawlAndAudit` `("CrawlAuditMode":"CrawlAndAudit")` `ScanStrategy` - When to perform the site Audit relative to a Crawl. Applicable only when `crawlAuditMode` is `CrawlAndAudit`. * `Simultaneously` - Crawl and audit at the same time to maximize scan speed (default). * `Sequentially` - Crawl the entire site before auditing. `webServiceScan` - allows to configure SOAP Web Service Scan: * `wsdName` - Webservice Test Design File name * `inheritWsdProxy` - use Webservice Test Design File proxy settings * `inheritWsdAuth` - use Webservice Test Design File network authentication settings `apiScan` - Configuration options for API scans: * `parserConfig` - A Base64 encoded string of an API Parser Config. To generate one, use the `configuration/apiParserConfig` family of endpoints. Must be defined by base settings or overrides. * `definitionUrl` - The URL of the cached API definition. (NOTE: If an API definition update is required, generate a new API parser config). * `type` - The type of API to be parsed (`Swagger`, `OData`, `GraphQL`, `gRPC`, `SOAP`) * `definitionAuth` - A string value designating the bearer token required to authenticate in order to retrieve the API Definition when using WISwag, if necessary(only available for ODATA and Swagger) `SharedThreads` - a number between 1 and 75 indicating the number of shared threads that the crawler and auditor should use (default is 1, meaning a single threaded scan). **`SharedThreads` is not compatible with `CrawlThreads` and `AuditThreads`. If `SharedThreads` is set, `CrawlThreads` and `AuditThreads` will be ignored.** `("SharedThreads":"1")` `CrawlThreads` - a number between 1 and 25 indicating the number of threads that the crawler should use (default is 1). **`SharedThreads` is not compatible with `CrawlThreads` and `AuditThreads`. If `SharedThreads` is set, `CrawlThreads` and `AuditThreads` will be ignored.** `("CrawlThreads":"1")` `AuditThreads` - a number between 1 and 50 indicating the number of threads that the auditor should use (default is 10). **`SharedThreads` is not compatible with `CrawlThreads` and `AuditThreads`. If `SharedThreads` is set, `CrawlThreads` and `AuditThreads` will be ignored.** `("AuditThreads":"10")` `LoginMacroAutoGen` - allows to configure automatic login macro generation (Optional): * `username` - login webform username * `password` - login webform password * `startUrl` - start scan URL or login webform URL (Optional) `LoginMacro` - a webmacro file name. This file must exist in the WebInspect scan settings folder on the WebInspect machine. `("LoginMacro":"mylogin")` `WorkflowMacros` - an array of webmacro file names to be used as workflow macros. These files must exist in the WebInspect scan settings folder on the WebInspect machine. `("WorkflowMacros":["workflow1","workflow2"])` `AllowedHosts` - an array of allowed host:port entries. Hosts found in `StartUrls` are automatically added to the allowed hosts list. Use the special value "\*" to add all hosts found in workflow macros, login macros and start urls to allowed hosts. **Caution! This is a convenience feature, and it can cause the scanner to go out of scope.** `("AllowedHosts":["zero.webappsecurity.com:80", "zero.webappsecurity.com:443", "myhost:8888"])` `("AllowedHosts":["\*"])` `PolicyId` - an integer representing the policy id OR the GUID representing the policy unique id. See /securebase/policy for a list of available policies. `("PolicyId":1)` `("PolicyId":"cb72a7c2-9207-4ee7-94d0-edd14a47c15c")` `PolicyPath` - the full path to the custom policy file. `("PolicyPath":"C:\ProgramData\HP\HP WebInspect\Policies\MyCustomPolicy.policy")` `CheckIDs` - an array of check IDs. A custom audit policy will be created from this list and used for the scan. `("CheckIDs":[100,200,300])` `TCMacroParameters` - override parameters defined in TruClient macros. The macros must exist in the scan settings and the parameters must exist in the macro. `("TCMacroParameters":{"mylogin":{"param1":"value1","param2":"value2"}})` `SmartCredentials` - override the smart credentials defined in a session-based macro. The macro must exist in the scan settings and smart credentials must be enabled in the macro. `("SmartCredentials":["myusername","mypassword"])` `userAgent` - allows to configure predefined user agent or use custom user agent string: * `standard` - options are: `firefox`, `internetexplorer`, `chrome`, `iphone`, `ipad`, `android`, `windowsphone`, `windowsrt`, `none`. (Optional). * `custom` - custom user agent string. (Optional). If you would like to use `custom` user agent string then `standard` should be set to `none` `("userAgent":{"standard":"firefox"})` `("userAgent":{"standard":"none","custom":"my custom user agent string"})` `proxy` - allows to configure proxy server: * `proxyMode` - options are: `none`, `standard`, `socks4`, `socks5`, `pacUrl`. (Required). * `proxyServer` - proxy server hostname or IP address. (Required). * `proxyPort` - proxy server port number. (Required) * `proxyPacUrl` - proxy server autoconfiguration PAC file URL. (Optional). * `proxyAuthType` - options are `none`, `basic`, `ntlm`, `kerberos`, `digest`, `automatic`, `negotiate`. (Optional). * `proxyAuthUsername` - proxy authentication username. (Optional). * `proxyAuthPassword` - proxy authentication password. (Optional). * `proxyBypass` - bypass proxy semicolon separated list (Optional). `("proxy": {"proxyMode":"standard","proxyServer":"myProxyHostOrIP","proxyPort":"8080"})` if you would like to use `proxyPacUrl` then `proxyMode` should be set to `pacUrl` `NetworkCredentials` - network authentication username and password. Use the `NetworkAuthenticationMode` setting to specify the authentication mode. `("NetworkCredentials":["myusername","mypassword"])` `NetworkAuthenticationMode` - modes are: `None`, `Basic`, `Digest`, `Kerberos`, `Negotiate`, `NTLM`, `ADFS_CBT`, `Automatic`. Specifies the network authentication mode when using `NetworkCredentials`. `("NetworkAuthenticationMode":"Basic")` `ScopedPaths` - list of folder restrictions. Paths found in `StartUrls` are automatically added to the `ScopedPaths` list. This setting interacts with `ScanScope` to determine which paths will be crawled during a scan. If `ScopedPaths` is specified, `ScanScope` must also be specified. `("ScopedPaths":["/ancestor/path1/","/ancestor/path2/"])` `ScanScope` - options are: `Unrestricted`, `Self`, `Children`, `Ancestors`. If `ScopedPaths` is specified, `ScanScope` must also be specified. `("ScanScope":"Unrestricted")` `ReuseScan` - a GUID representing an existing scan ID. The scan referenced by the `ReuseScan` parameter is used as a baseline. The `ReuseScanMode` parameter determines the manner in which the baseline scan is reused. `("ReuseScan":"98451e29-8209-4286-a9dc-b686c64fc30c","ReuseScanMode":"Incremental")` `ReuseScanMode` - This parameter works together with `ReuseScan` to determine how the baseline scan is used. Options are: * `Incremental` - A new scan is created and seeded with crawl sessions from the baseline scan. When the incremental scan is complete, you can then merge it back into the baseline scan so that the baseline now contains any additional crawl sessions or vulnerabilities that were discovered. See the /scanner/merge endpoint for more information. * `Remediation` - A new scan is created without seeding data from the baseline scan. A policy is created which only includes checks that were flagged in the baseline scan. * `ReuseCrawl` - A new scan is created and seeded with crawl sessions from the baseline scan. This setting interacts with `ScopedPaths` to restrict the crawler to specific paths within a web site: * `Unrestricted` - `ScopedPaths` is ignored. Crawl all discovered paths, but respect allowed host rules. * `Self` - limit crawl strictly to paths listed in `ScopedPaths`. Referring to the example in `ScopedPaths`, /ancestor/path1/ would be allowed but /ancestor/ and /ancestor/path1/child/ would be excluded from crawl. * `Children` - limit crawl to paths listed in `ScopedPaths` and their children. Referring to the example in `ScopedPaths`, /ancestor/path1/ and /ancestor/path1/child/ would be allowed but /ancestor/ would be excluded from crawl. * `Ancestors` - limit crawl to paths listed in `ScopedPaths` and their parents. Referring to the example in `ScopedPaths`, /ancestor/path1/ and /ancestor/ would be allowed but /ancestor/path1/child/ would be excluded from crawl. `DontStartScan` - options are: `true`, `false`. If true, the scan will be created using the `settingsName` and `overrides` options, but it will remain in the stopped state. `("DontStartScan":true)` `ClientCertificate` - either the location of the client certificate in the Windows certificate store OR the raw client certificate. * `Enabled` - User can manually disable(false) or enable(true) it. Default it will be true if `StoreName` and `SerialNumber` or `Bytes` provided in other cases false. If you want to reference a client certificate in the Windows certificate store, use these fields: * `IsGlobal` - if true, look for `StoreName` in the Local Machine machine hive. Otherwise look for `StoreName` in the Current User hive. * `StoreName` - the system store name where the certificate is located. The predefined systems stores are: MY, Root, Trust, CA. * `SerialNumber` - the serial number that uniquely identifies the client certificate. If you want to embed the client certificate, use this field: * `Bytes` - the raw client certificate bytes in base64 encoded format. If this field is set then the values of `IsGlobal`, `StoreName` and `SerialNumber` are ignored. **Caution! When using the `Bytes` option, the client certificate is embedded in the scan settings and may be visible to other users.** * `Password` - client pfx certificate password. (Optional). `redundantPageDetection` - Compares the page structure of each crawled page to identify and exclude processing of redundant resources. * `enabled` - `true` to enable the Redundant Page Detection feature, or `false` to disable it. If undefined in both base settings and request, defaults to `false`. * `pageSimilarityThresholdPercentage` - How similar a page must be to another to be considered redundant, in terms of a percentage.
This value **must** be an integer within [1, 100]. If undefined in both base settings and request, defaults to 95. * `includedTagAttributes` - A comma-separated list of tag attributes to be included in the page structure comparison. If undefined or empty in both base settings and request, defaults to `"id,class"`. `reuseFP` - allows to specify array of ScanIDs to import false positives from scans containing vulnerabilities that were changed to false positives. If those false positives match vulnerabilities detected in this scan, the vulnerabilities will be changed to false positives `("reuseFP":["98451e29-8209-4286-a9dc-b686c64fc30c"])` `ProxySettingsType` - indicates the Proxy Settings type. This value is ignored if `proxy` is specified. `("ProxySettingsType":"AutoDetect")` `SPAEnabledOption` - Indicates the Single-Page Applications enabled option. `("SPAEnabledOption":"Auto")` `SessionExclusions` - list of Other Exlusion/Rejection Criteria. `("SessionExclusions": [{"name": "exclusionName", "reject": true, "exclude": true, "targets": [{ "targetType": "QueryParameter", "targetName": "targetNameValue", "matchType": "Matches", "matchString": "matchStringValue" }] }])` `RequestParameterInfo` - RequestParameterInfo settings. `("RequestParameterInfo": [{"requestParameterInfoAuditMode": "CompatibleTypesOnly", "requestParameterInfoFileNames": ["file.json"])` ###Examples### ~~~~ #start a scan using the Default scan settings curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "settingsName": "Default" }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans #start a scan using the Default scan settings, set the scan name to "My Scan Name", use a login macro named tclogin, and use the "Criticals and Highs" policy curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "settingsName": "Default", "overrides": { "scanName": "My Scan Name", "loginMacro": "tclogin", "policyId":1008 } }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans #start a scan using a scan settings file named MySettings.xml, use Basic network authentication and set the username to "myusername" and the password to "mypassword" curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "settingsName": "MySettings", "overrides": { "networkAuthenticationMode": "basic", "networkCredentials": ["myusername","mypassword"] } }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans #start a scan using the Default scan settings, use a TruClient based login macro named tclogin.webmacro, set the macro parameter named "username" to "myusername" and the parameter named "password" to "mypassword" (these parameters must exist in the macro) curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "settingsName": "Default", "overrides": { "loginMacro": "tclogin", "tcMacroParameters": { "tclogin": { "username":"myusername", "password":"mypassword" } } } }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans #start a scan using the Default scan settings, change the scan type to a workflow macro scan, use the workflow macro named MyWorkflow, and set the scan mode to audit only curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "settingsName": "Default", "overrides": { "startOption": "macro", "workflowMacros": ["MyWorkflow"], "crawlAuditMode": "auditOnly"} }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans #start a scan using the Default scan settings, set the start url to http://myhost/appPath/, restrict the scan to only crawl within /appPath/ and any sub-folders under /appPath/ curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "settingsName": "Default", "overrides": { "startUrls": ["http://myhost/appPath/"], "scanScope": "children"} }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans #start a scan using the Default scan settings, set the start url to http://myhost/appPath/, restrict the scan to only crawl within /appPath/ and /appPath/level1/ curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "settingsName": "Default", "overrides": { "startUrls": ["http://myhost/appPath/"], "scanScope": "self", "scopedPaths": ["/appPath/","/appPath/level1/"] } }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans #start an incremental scan using an existing scan as the baseline (overrides could be specified, but settingsName is ignored) curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "reuseScan":{"scanId":"98451e29-8209-4286-a9dc-b686c64fc30c","mode":"Incremental"} }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans ~~~~

parameters.name: startScanSettings
parameters.description: Options used to start a scan. `settingsName` is required. `overrides` and `reuseScan` are optional. When `reuseScan` parameters are specified, `settingsName` should still be sent, but it is ignored and should be an empty value. In the scan reuse case the settings from the reused scan will be used. Overrides can be applied to reuse scan settings.

get.summary: Generate a report from a scan.
get.description:
The report is generated to the specified format and downloaded to your client.
###Examples###
~~~~
#generate a Vulnerability report
curl http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/reports/{scanId}.scan?reportType=Standard&reportName=Vulnerability
~~~~

parameters.name: scanId
parameters.description: The scan GUID.

parameters.name: reportFormat
parameters.description:
The `reportFormat` value specifies the format of the exported report. It must be one of:
* `pdf`
* `html`
* `raw`
* `rtf`
* `txt`
* `excel`

parameters.name: reportType
parameters.description:
Indicates whether the `reportName` parameter represents an issue report or a compliance template. Must be one of:
* `issue`
* `compliance`

parameters.name: reportName
parameters.description: If the value of reportType is `compliance`, then the value of `reportName` must be the name of a compliance template. If the value of reportType is `issue`, then the value of `reportName` must the name of a custom report OR one of the following standard reports (Aggregate is not supported): * `Alert View` * `Attack Status` * `Crawled URLS` * `Developer Reference` * `Duplicates` * `Executive Summary` * `False Positive` * `QA Summary` * `Scan Difference` * `Scan Log` * `Trend` * `Vulnerability` * `Vulnerability (Legacy)` See GET /scanner/reports for a list of all available reports.

parameters.name: isCustom
parameters.description: Indicates whether the `reportName` parameter represents a standard or custom report.

put.description:
This endpoint will invoke the WISwag tool and convert a REST API definition into a WebInspect settings or macro file. 
The request body format is described in the WebInspect help or by running "WISwag.exe ?" from the command line.
The generated scan settings file will be placed into the WebInspect scan settings folder as defined by the WebInspect application setting (C:\ProgramData\HP\HP WebInspect\Settings by default).
###Examples###
~~~~
#create a WebInspect scan settings from a Swagger definition
curl -X PUT -d "{\"config\":{\"apiDefinition\":\"http://petstore.swagger.io/v2/swagger.json\"}, \"outputType\":\"settings\", \"outputName\":\"Petstore\"}" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/wiswag
~~~~

post.summary: Invoke the WISwag tool with file references.
post.description:
This endpoint will invoke the WISwag tool and convert a REST API definition into a WebInspect settings or macro file.

Use this endpoint if the WISwag configuration contains file references.

1. Create a zip archive that contains a file named config.wiswag. The config.wiswag file format is the json request object described in the PUT /scanner/wiswag endpoint.
2. Add any files that are referenced by config.wiswag to the zip archive.
3. Upload the zip archive to this endpoint.

The generated scan settings file will be placed into the WebInspect scan settings folder as defined by the WebInspect application setting (the default location is C:\ProgramData\HP\HP WebInspect\Settings).

The request must be formatted as `multipart/form-data`.
###Examples###
~~~~
#upload a WISwag configuration archive and convert it to a WebInspect scan settings
curl -X POST -F "file=@/local/path/myAPIDefinition.zip" http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/wiswag


#sample HTTP request
POST /webinspect/api/v1/scanner/wiswag HTTP/1.1
Host: myhost
Content-Length: xxx
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=----FormBoundaryd6c9T0mlmNbct6Uq

------FormBoundaryd6c9T0mlmNbct6Uq
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="wiswagConfig"; filename="myAPIDefinition.zip"
Content-Type: text/xml

{zip file contents here}
------FormBoundaryd6c9T0mlmNbct6Uq--

~~~~

parameters.name: wiswagConfig
parameters.description: The WISwag configuration file to upload.

post.description:
Merge multiple existing scans into a single scan.

`name` - (optional) any alpha-numeric value, does not need to be unique. This will be the name of the merged scan *except* in the case of an `incremental` merge. In the `incremental` case the incremental scan(s) are merged into the baseline and the name of the baseline is unchanged.
`("name":"My Merged Scan")`

`scanIds` - a list of valid scan GUIDs that are used in the merge operation.
`("scanIds":["", ""])`

`mode` - Determines how the merge operation is to be carried out. Options are:
* `incremental` - Incremental scans are merged into their baseline. A new scan is *not* created. After the merge operation is complete, the baseline will be the union of the baseline and the specified incremental scans. This mode is only valid if the `scanIds` list consists of a baseline scan and *only* incremental scans created from that baseline scan. Any attempt to do an `incremental` merge of non-incremental scans, or an `incremental` merge of incremental scans into a scan that is not the baseline of those incremental scans will fail.
* `replace` - A new scan is automatically created and used as the merge target. While merging the scans specified by the `scanIds`, when sessions collide, replace the target session with the source session and replace target vulns with the source vulns.
* `append`  - A new scan is automatically created and used as the merge target. While merging the scans specified by the `scanIds`, when sessions collide, replace the target session with the source session and add source vulns to the target scan.

###Examples###
~~~~
#merge 3 scans, if any sessions conflict, use the session from the latest scan but keep all of the vulns from any of the scans that also have the conflicting session
curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "name": "My Merged Scan", "scanIds": ["98451e29-8209-4286-a9dc-b686c64fc30a", "98451e29-8209-4286-a9dc-b686c64fc30b", "98451e29-8209-4286-a9dc-b686c64fc30c"], "mode": "append" }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans/merge

#incremental merge is a special case:
#first, do the incremental merge (in this case, one scan is a baseline, the other must be an incremental scan created from that baseline).
curl -X POST --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json' -d '{ "scanIds": ["98451e29-8209-4286-a9dc-baseline", "98451e29-8209-4286-a9dc-incremental"], "mode": "incremental" }' http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scans/merge

#now that the incremental scan is merged into the baseline, we can delete the incremental scan.
curl -X DELETE http://autotmpwin10:8083/webinspect/api/v1/scanner/scanner/scans/98451e29-8209-4286-a9dc-incremental
~~~~

parameters.name: mergeScan
parameters.description: The scan GUIDs to merge, the manner in which to merge the scans and optionally the name of the merged scan. See Implementation Notes for more detail.
